text: Right, and now remedied in Maine.
author: JamesFallows

text: But in general election, candidates *already* don’t campaign in ND, SD, OK, NE, WY, WV, most of the South, most of the big states, or *anywhere* but OH, PA, FL, WI. MI, because only those few states are “in play.”  Hard to see this as either intentional or beneficial.
author: JamesFallows

text:
Genuine question: 

If this is such a danger, why hasn’t it happened in any of the states, which already elect Governors by popular vote, rather than a county-based counterpart to EC?
author: JamesFallows

text: Thank you!
author: JamesFallows
JamesFallows

text: Excellent point
author: JamesFallows

text:
Good lord. 

The *northeastern US,* which you see in the “New York” area, contains twice as many people as Texas.  You can look it up. 

But, have it your way.
author: JamesFallows

text:
Incorrect. The vertical height is scaled to the population of each county; the color is blue-purple-red based on vote. 

You can look it up:  https://vanderbei.princeton.edu/JAVA/election2016/ …

text:
This is well argued.

-S Moore—affable and personally gracious—came to Trump’s notice because he’s so ironclad a defend-Trump-no-matter-what stalwart on cable news.

-For exactly that reason, he is not a good candidate as a Fed governor

“Good on cable"≠judicious temperament.
author: JamesFallows

text:
If divine orchestration of worldly events were completely thoroughgoing, Mueller would be handing over his report at this instant:

End-of-days hail, lightning, black skies, gale-force winds, whipping through DC just now. 

(But report will probably emerge on a mild sunny day.)
author: JamesFallows

text: And how! Just landed, from Indiana, glad not landing now.

text:
What??

You will find no case whatsoever of a comparable move: head of govt, l’etat c’est moi, publicly voiding (on a whim?) ruling from his own administration. Let alone one involving North Korea.

Hey, GOP SENATE MAJORITY.  Anything to notice here???
author: JamesFallows

text: Indeed!  That’s the point of the article, as you’ll see  — and was the basis of the DC City Council’s unanimous approval of the measure.

text:
Brian Williams just now on MSNBC: “Jimmy Carter has been the most exemplary post-president in our nation’s history.”
 -Today JEC becomes longest-lived ex-prez in US history (passing GHWB)
 -Has already been ex-prez *9.5 times* longer than he was in office
-B Williams is right.

text:
Winding up week in Hoosier-land under auspices of @INHumanities  and @NewAmerica Indy, w about 100 leads to pursue in Muncie, Indy, Ft Wayne, and tonight Angola. 

(ZERO of them involving ‘how does The Heartland think about Trump?’ etc. So many other things afoot.)
author: JamesFallows

text: This place is incredible, in a good way.
author: JamesFallows

text:
Airlines in some parts of the world  have become exceptionally safe. In other parts of the world, they haven’t. 
Data and some hypotheses about the differences, from @TheAtlantic readers, here
author: JamesFallows

text: I hope that when video of this session is available, people will check it out. A different discussion of “heartland,” “big cities,” coast-vs-interior, representation-and-diversity than you’ll usually get on TV.  Thanks to @iSmashfizzle @INHumanities @NewAmerica @IndianaTech et al

author: JamesFallows

text:
With aviation safety in the news, this video very informative on complex relation of tech, training, culture in reducing fatal accidents in small airplanes. Worth watching.

(Re parachute for Cirrus, kind of plane I got as soon as came on market in 2000.)
author: JamesFallows

text:
A ringing defense of Indiana in specific, and Midwest in general, as natural home to the *diversity,* the practicality, the *space* of the next version of American renewal.
Time for ambitious young Americans to start moving back
 By @iSmashFizzle 
@INHumanities @NewAmerica Indy
author: JamesFallows

text:
Closest margin in modern times was  100,000+ votes (JFK / Nixon 1960). Second closest, 500,000+  (Humphrey, in loss to Nixon 1968, Gore in pop-vote majority over GWB in 2000.) 
  So, not a few hundred.
author: JamesFallows

text:
2/2 
Don’t believe me? Go back and read political accts and popular histories of 1980s and 1990s. EC/Pop Vote difference was described as interesting potential anomaly.

Any pro-EC arg saying “oh, cities would be too dominant” would logically apply to gov and sen races as well.
author: JamesFallows

text:
1/2 Actual case “for” the Elect College: as of Nov 6, 2000, NO LIVING AMERICAN VOTER had seen EC “winner” differ from person who got most votes. (Before that, happened in 1888.) It was seen by both sides as quaint thought-experiment formalism.
Now 2 of past 3 prez chosen that way
author: JamesFallows

text: More details TK (and many still unknown), but a difference between this and, say, clogged pitot tube is that *if* pilots knew of the trim defect, presumably they could override it and continue the flight.  With a failed pitot system, you’re in much bigger trouble. But stay tuned.
author: JamesFallows

text:
Yes, one of the (many many) issues here is apparent single-source dependence for AOA reading.  
Whole different subject of maintenance practices as Lion Air. (I have no info on this latter point.)

If confirmed, significant in emphasizing the crucial role of training & familiarity in safe operation of this plane.

text:
Juliette, slightly different:

 - Pilots who *knew how this airplane worked* could and would fly it without problem (and have done so). See: https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2019/03/training-regulation-and-737-max/585142/ …

- *The* question is whether air crews around the world were informed how this new model works.

text:
Rear-ended just now while at (red) stoplight en route DCA. Low speed, no one hurt, no harm no foul.
 But other driver, 40s-ish parent w 3 kids in car, was clearly texting at the time. 
Data point, for a problem driverless cars  might help solve. Or something should solve.
author: JamesFallows

text:
On Face the Nation, Mick Mulvaney turns *every* question about rise of white supremacy into “Why do people keep unfairly blaming everything on Donald Trump?”
If you think this is exaggeration, check it out later on.
It is the “using TV to reach an audience of one” pattern again.

The government tries like crazy to regiment it. And yet people live their own way.

author: JamesFallows

text:
National Popular Vote initiative is the way to go.  https://www.nationalpopularvote.com/ 

This would already have happened if ~80,000 votes in Ohio had gone other way in 2004. (Kerry would have lost popular vote but won Electoral College over GWB.  Then GOP would have cared about EC reform.)
author: JamesFallows

text:
You’re kidding, right?
- Monash shooting was *seventeen* years ago.

*This* is your example of how Aussie gun control has not worked?  (This happens several times a week in US.)
author: JamesFallows

text: Yes: and (1) substantial controls on semi-automatics like AR-15, plus (2) NO recurrence of large-scale massacres. “River whatever” [Margaret River] was grandparent shooting his family.

text:

The Farmers ads seem like Geico, Progressive, etc: trying to bring some levity to ads for a necessary-but-unexciting product.

author: JamesFallows

text: Correct, the word “failure” is not used here.
author: JamesFallows

text:
2/2 There was a whole book about the speech and its influence:
https://www.amazon.com/What-Heck-Are-You-President/dp/B005FOGZLO …

Problems began when Carter dismissed Cabinet not long afterwards. And .. all the rest. But dissing of speech itself is ahistorical. 
 
(For the record, I was not involved in it. Had left.)
author: JamesFallows

text:
1/2 Alas repeats canard that Carter’s 1979 “Crisis of Confidence” speech (aka “malaise,” word he didn’t use) was a failure. 

In fact speech was praised and  popular at the time. Raised Carter’s approval rating by *10 points.*
author: JamesFallows

text: 2/2 A quote from the story:
